title.narrative: INDO - Marunda Urban Resilience in Action Phase II

description.narrative:
Overall goal: Marunda community with the support of the engaged stakeholders in the MURIA Platform has developed resilient, sustainable livelihoods serving as a model of urban resilience for replication in other areas
Specific objectives:
1. To make clean water available and accessible for consumption, sanitation and livelihood development in Marunda and the upstream communities in Cakung watershed 2. To develop business opportunities through strengthening of entrepreneurial capacities, risk management, access to finance and market linkages 3. To reduce damage to livelihood assets and resources because of flood risk reducing plans and measures in Marunda and upstream communities of Cakung watershed

The Marunda Urban Resilience in Action (MURIA) project, initiated by Cordaid and Karina Yogyakarta in August 2015 and continuing until now, has successfully established the MURIA multi-stakeholder platform in Marunda, North Jakarta, and provided development options for the urban poor.
The MURIA multi-stakeholders platform was established to formulate a common agenda in developing Marunda and to enable the platform members to collaborate with other members or run their own program in strengthening urban resilience. Considering the various risks and challenges found in Marunda, the MURIA Platform has created the space to discuss and develop smart solutions towards the problems and challenges in Marunda.
The next phase of the MURIA project (2018-2019) continues in strengthening the MURIA Platform and advancing the multi-stakeholder approach in developing solutions to reduce the problems of flooding, improve water quality and sanitation and increase livelihood options. Building on valuable lessons as well as a gap analysis Cordaid proposes to expand the working area to upstream communities in the same sub-watershed area, to enhance addressing problems of flooding in a more comprehensive way and increasing and improving market opportunities for urban farming and other businesses by establishing linkages between Marunda and other selected communities.
The total number of direct beneficiaries is 1990 households and 35 stakeholders from government, private sector, knowledge institutes and civil society.

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

title.narrative: Sustainable Livelihoods Thematic Indicators
Number of DRR/Resilience committees established and functioning at local level
Number of communities reached (RI)
Number of CSOs/NGOs able to facilitate a community managed resilience/DRR process
Number of Resilience Action Plans developed at community/local level

description.narrative: Number of communities which have been supported by Cordaid and/or partners and developed joint action plans to enhance resilience at the community/local level

title.narrative: Number of Participatory Disaster Risk Analysis (PDRAs) done at community/local level
Number of direct beneficiaries enhanced their resilience through community level resilience activities
Number of communities implementing Resilience measures

description.narrative: Number of targeted communities which have been supported by Cordaid and/or partners and (raise funds for and) carry out their action plans by implementing resilience interventions at the community/ local level

title.narrative: Number of CSOs/NGOs influencing government, donor agencies and/or investors regarding the inclusion of (community) resilience in selected policies, development programmes and/or investments

description.narrative: Number of CSOs/NGOs who have been trained by Cordaid and/or partners on lobby and advocacy and who are using their enhanced L&A capacity to advocate for the inclusion of resilience elements in donor or government policies and/or programmes

title.narrative: Number of Resilience Action Plans developed at district/municipality level, through a multi-stakeholder process

description.narrative: Number of action plans which have been jointly developed by multiple stakeholders to enhance resilience at the district/municipality level with support of Cordaid and/or partners

title.narrative: Number of targeted policies with an improved inclusion of (community) resilience

description.narrative: Number of local, regional, national or international policies which have been positively influenced by Cordaid or partner CSOs/NGOs and have an improved inclusion of resilience elements

title.narrative: Number of targeted programmes with an improved inclusion of (community) resilience

description.narrative: Number of local, regional, national or international programmes which have been positively influenced by Cordaid or partner CSOs/NGOs and have an improved inclusion of resilience elements

title.narrative: Number of multi-stakeholder platforms at district/municipality level implementing the planned resilience measures

description.narrative: Number of multi-stakeholder platforms which have been supported by Cordaid and/or partners and (raise funds for and) carry out their action plans by implementing resilience interventions at the district/municipality level

title.narrative: Number of CSOs/NGOs and other stakeholders able to collaborate/facilitate the resilience process at district/municipality level

description.narrative: Other stakeholders include government, private sector, INGOs; (Note: process has 5 key steps: participatory disaster risk analysis, joint resilience action planning, confirmed set-up of multi-stakeholder platform, implementation of resilience action plan, and M&E and advocacy)

title.narrative: Number of advocacy trajectories done by CSOs and/or Cordaid towards government parties and/or donors, regarding the inclusion of resilience in their policies

description.narrative: Supported / funded by Cordaid private funds (MiN) or other backdonors (non-PfR)

title.narrative: Number of publications/other materials on enhanced (community) resilience ("evidence") made by CSO/NGO partners and/or field staff

description.narrative: Supported / funded by Cordaid private funds (MiN) or other backdonors (non-PfR)
